DIALOGUE BEFORE: NPCMAlanBinet: Ah, it's you. You're finally with us.
RESPONSE TEXT: I'd just like to apologize for any... trouble... our synths may have caused for you on your way here.
They of course couldn't be told of your identity, and they have very specific protocols for protecting themselves and Institute interests...
Most of which I designed myself. Not to make problems for you, though. I, err, will you be staying with us, then?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Yes, of course.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Yes, of course.
RESPONSE TEXT: Ah, good. Shaun is most pleased, I'm sure. He's been quite anxious to have you with us.
DIALOGUE AFTER: AlanBinet: If you require anything, especially as it pertains to synths, please let me know.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Not a chance.
RESPONSE TEXT: No? I... hmm. Well, I'm sure Shaun is... quite disappointed.
SCRIPT NOTES: Surprised, uncertain, not what you expected

RESPONSE TEXT: I do hope you reconsider.
DIALOGUE AFTER: AlanBinet: If you require anything, especially as it pertains to synths, please let me know.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm thinking it over.
RESPONSE TEXT: Well I hope you do decide to stay. It would mean a great deal to Shaun.
DIALOGUE AFTER: AlanBinet: If you require anything, especially as it pertains to synths, please let me know.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What's it to you?
RESPONSE TEXT: Oh, forgive me, I realize... well, I understand that's somewhat personal. It would just mean a great deal to Shaun.
DIALOGUE AFTER: AlanBinet: If you require anything, especially as it pertains to synths, please let me know.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Ah, good. Shaun is most pleased, I'm sure. He's been quite anxious to have you with us.
RESPONSE TEXT: If you require anything, especially as it pertains to synths, please let me know.
You must feel a bit overwhelmed.
SCRIPT NOTES: Filling an awkward pause in the conversation... the player has stopped talking

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah, it's you. You're finally with us.
DIALOGUE AFTER: AlanBinet: I'd just like to apologize for any... trouble... our synths may have caused for you on your way here.

RESPONSE TEXT: The synths are treating you well, I hope?
I don't know if you've noticed, but I've increased synth responsiveness by .04 percent.
Another lovely day, isn't it?
Today is full of possibilities.
We're quite fortunate to have the synths to aid us.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: There's a remote access entry in the log. It came from your quarters.
RESPONSE TEXT: Let me guess, terminal three?
It has been acting a bit strange of late. Probably needs maintenance. I wouldn't pay any attention to it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: Carry on with your investigation, if you wish. You'll find nothing to incriminate me, I promise you that.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Just trying to cover all the bases.
RESPONSE TEXT: How thorough of you.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: Carry on with your investigation, if you wish. You'll find nothing to incriminate me, I promise you that.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Possibly.
RESPONSE TEXT: You're a cagey one, aren't you?
I can see why Justin chose to send you in his stead. You're very alike in that way.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: Carry on with your investigation, if you wish. You'll find nothing to incriminate me, I promise you that.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Is there someone who would want to?
RESPONSE TEXT: The only people who have any interest in the synth lab already have access to those computers.
If they wanted to log in remotely, they could do so from their own quarters.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: Carry on with your investigation, if you wish. You'll find nothing to incriminate me, I promise you that.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: It has been acting a bit strange of late. Probably needs maintenance. I wouldn't pay any attention to it.
RESPONSE TEXT: Carry on with your investigation, if you wish. You'll find nothing to incriminate me, I promise you that.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I believe you, but I still need answers.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: PlayerVoiceFemale01: Do you ever log in from your quarters?
RESPONSE TEXT: Goodness no. When I retire for the day, I put any thought of work out of my mind.
I find that keeping a balance between my work and my leisure time is vital for healthy living.
Do you suspect that someone has logged into one of the laboratory terminals from my quarters?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: There's a remote access entry in the log. It came from your quarters.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I believe you, but I still need answers.
RESPONSE TEXT: Then do what you must, but leave me out of it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: I think that's quite enough for now. Goodbye.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'd better not.
RESPONSE TEXT: If you think I can be intimidated by the likes of you, I'm afraid you are quite mistaken.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: I think that's quite enough for now. Goodbye.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: We'll see.
RESPONSE TEXT: Indeed we will.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: I think that's quite enough for now. Goodbye.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What if it's a frame job? Who would benefit if you looked guilty?
RESPONSE TEXT: A frame job? What is that, some pre-war vernacular for blaming the innocent?
I assure you, that sort of thing does not happen here.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: I think that's quite enough for now. Goodbye.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Then do what you must, but leave me out of it.
RESPONSE TEXT: I think that's quite enough for now. Goodbye.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Justin Ayo thinks you're helping synths escape. I need to know the truth.
RESPONSE TEXT: I see. The man does not lack for tenacity.
He is however, completely wrong about me.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: Ayo and his Courser goons have already scoured my laboratory for evidence. Feel free to do the same, if you think you must.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You're helping synths escape, and I'm going to prove it.
RESPONSE TEXT: What?! I'm not doing anything of the sort!
Let me guess... Justin Ayo put you up to this, didn't he?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: Ayo and his Courser goons have already scoured my laboratory for evidence. Feel free to do the same, if you think you must.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I can't discuss it. Just go back to what you were doing.
RESPONSE TEXT: Wait a minute... did Justin Ayo send you here to look through these terminals?
Yes... I suspect he did.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: Ayo and his Courser goons have already scoured my laboratory for evidence. Feel free to do the same, if you think you must.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Are you helping synths escape from the Institute, Doctor Binet?
RESPONSE TEXT: Not this nonsense again.
I suppose this means that Justin Ayo has given up trying to wring a confession from me himself.
Now he's using you to do his dirty work instead.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: Ayo and his Courser goons have already scoured my laboratory for evidence. Feel free to do the same, if you think you must.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: He is however, completely wrong about me.
RESPONSE TEXT: Ayo and his Courser goons have already scoured my laboratory for evidence. Feel free to do the same, if you think you must.
If there's something specific you want to ask me, then get on with it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Why would Ayo think you were helping synths?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Why would Ayo think you were helping synths?
RESPONSE TEXT: He probably thinks my admiration for the synths might have caused me to have some delusion about setting them free.
The notion is preposterous. The last thing I'd want to do is banish a synth to the surface. It's a living hell up there.
That's not freedom, it's a death sentence. I would never be so cruel.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Why would Ayo think you were helping synths?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: We're done.
RESPONSE TEXT: Very well.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Does anyone else have access to your terminals?
RESPONSE TEXT: Unlikely. I don't let anyone else lay a finger on my terminals without my close supervision.
I'll make an exception in your case, however. If Father trusts you, then I have no reason not to.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Why would Ayo think you were helping synths?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: How many synths have escaped?
RESPONSE TEXT: I'm not sure of the exact number, but I can tell you the rate of escapes has accelerated greatly in recent months.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Why would Ayo think you were helping synths?

RESPONSE TEXT: This is unacceptable. Absolutely unacceptable.
SCRIPT NOTES: Talking quietly to yourself. Indignant, annoyed.

RESPONSE TEXT: Can't believe he would accuse me...
SCRIPT NOTES: Talking quietly to yourself. Indignant, annoyed.

RESPONSE TEXT: He's gone too far this time.
SCRIPT NOTES: Talking quietly to yourself. Indignant, annoyed.

RESPONSE TEXT: The nerve of that man!
SCRIPT NOTES: Talking quietly to yourself. Indignant, annoyed.

RESPONSE TEXT: You'd think Justin Ayo would have better ways to spend his time than to make ridiculous accusations.
All I want is to be able to work in peace! Is that so much to ask?
Why would anyone think I'd be so cruel as to set a synth free on the surface? It's preposterous!
I do miss Doctor Zimmer. If he were here, none of this nonsense would be happening.
Our synths are truly remarkable. Every day they manage to surprise me. Now, what can I do for you?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Justin Ayo thinks you're helping synths escape. I need to know the truth.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Max: It was probably just a glitch in the nervous system. The fine motor control software could use an update.
RESPONSE TEXT: If it were just a limb twitching, perhaps, but her eyes were moving as well.
Involuntary twitching and rapid eye movements while sleeping can only mean one thing, Max.
You just don't want to admit to yourself what it is.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Max: If you're about to launch into one of your impassioned speeches about artificial sentience and machines with souls, don't bother.
SCRIPT NOTES: Excitement, a new discovery, then accusing

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Max: I've heard enough of them by now. Hell, I could write them down from memory.
RESPONSE TEXT: But we can't just ignore the question. If a synth can dream, why can't it have a soul?
And if a synth has a soul, then it is a living person by every standard we can measure.
Of course, it's far more comfortable to think of them as machines, so we can do what we want with them.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Max: If you disapprove of the work we do here, Doctor Binet, you know where to find the teleporter.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Max: If you disapprove of the work we do here, Doctor Binet, you know where to find the teleporter.
RESPONSE TEXT: Now just a moment, I never said that.
I'm simply trying to open everyone's eyes to new possibilities.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Max: Well it's an unwanted distraction.

RESPONSE TEXT: Sounds like some of the gen 2s are acting up.
SCRIPT NOTES: More annoyance than concern. Gen 2s is "gen (as in generation) twos"

RESPONSE TEXT: Something about a twitch in the right hand that's affecting their manual dexterity.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Max: Yes, I've seen the same thing myself a time or two.

RESPONSE TEXT: SRB says one of their Coursers is suddenly speaking Mandarin instead of English.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Max: Yes, I've seen the same thing myself a time or two.

RESPONSE TEXT: You see that report from Facilities?
A couple of their gen 1s were trying to walk into walls. Sounds like a pathfinding bug to me.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Max: Yes, I've seen the same thing myself a time or two.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Max: I made a note to look into it when there's time.
RESPONSE TEXT: Sounds like you're on top of things, then.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Max: I made a note to look into it when there's time.
RESPONSE TEXT: Very well, I'll leave it in your capable hands.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Max: I made a note to look into it when there's time.
RESPONSE TEXT: Good enough for me.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Max: I'm swamped right now. Can you accomodate them?
RESPONSE TEXT: I'll see what I can do.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Max: Thanks.
SCRIPT NOTES: Resignation. You are taking on extra work.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Max: I'm swamped right now. Can you accomodate them?
RESPONSE TEXT: No promises, but I'll try to fit it in where I can.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Max: Thanks.
SCRIPT NOTES: Resignation. You are taking on extra work.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Max: I'm swamped right now. Can you accomodate them?
RESPONSE TEXT: It'll take a few days, but I should be able to get it done.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Max: Thanks.
SCRIPT NOTES: Resignation. You are taking on extra work.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Max: How's that personal synth of yours working out? I've heard that Liam's grown quite attached to it.
RESPONSE TEXT: Not "it", Doctor Loken, "she." And she has a name.
To answer your question, Eve has been an indispensable companion, both to Liam and myself.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Max: Alan, I know it's been difficult for you since you lost your wife, but don't lose perspective.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Max: A synth might look like a man or a woman, but it isn't. It's not healthy to become too attached.
RESPONSE TEXT: Need I remind you, Doctor Loken, that in biochemical terms a human being is also a machine.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Max: Don't hide behind technicalities, Alan. I'm your friend. I'm not judging you, but others will.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Max: Such behavior could be construed as deviant. You know where that will lead.
RESPONSE TEXT: There's no need to get worked up over it, Max. I'm simply carrying out an experiment.
I believe that our third-generation synths are sophisticated enough to form social bonds, even familial bonds.
Only through close observation can I prove my hypothesis.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Max: Alright, Alan. I'll trust your judgement on this. Just be careful.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: NPCMAlanBinet: Ah, director, hello. If I may take a moment of your time, we're having some trouble on the surface.
RESPONSE TEXT: There's a den of those abominable Feral Ghouls that's been threatening one of our scavenger teams.
SCRIPT NOTES: A mix of worried and annoyed - DO NOT RE-RECORD (just fixed capitalization) / Disgust

RESPONSE TEXT: We've had to recall the synth scavengers until the situation can be dealt with, hopefully by you.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I took care of them already.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I took care of them already.
RESPONSE TEXT: I'm very grateful for your help.
DIALOGUE AFTER: QuestGiver: I have no firsthand experience with these creatures, of course, but I've heard that they can be quite vicious.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Send someone else. One of your Coursers, maybe.
RESPONSE TEXT: That's against SRB policy, unfortunately. I'm afraid you're the only option.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I took care of them already.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I don't know. I've got a lot on my plate right now.
RESPONSE TEXT: I wouldn't ask if it wasn't important. Please, there's no one else I can turn to.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I took care of them already.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Do you know where these Feral Ghouls are coming from?
RESPONSE TEXT: We have a pretty good idea, yes. So you'll take the mission?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I took care of them already.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm very grateful for your help.
RESPONSE TEXT: I have no firsthand experience with these creatures, of course, but I've heard that they can be quite vicious.
They are also quite territorial, so you should prepare for a fight.
Good luck.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: PlayerVoiceFemale01: Those Feral Ghouls won't be a problem any more.
RESPONSE TEXT: Splendid! And you hardly seem the worse for wear. Remarkable.
Father said that you were a soldier. You must have been a good one.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I won my share of medals.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I won my share of medals.
RESPONSE TEXT: I don't doubt it. Not even a bit.
DIALOGUE AFTER: QuestGiver: Thanks to you, I can finally send that scavenger team back to the surface.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Nothing special. Just a regular grunt.
RESPONSE TEXT: I'm in no position to argue, but you've certainly made an impression on me.
DIALOGUE AFTER: QuestGiver: Thanks to you, I can finally send that scavenger team back to the surface.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I wish my old C.O. were around to hear this.
RESPONSE TEXT: Who knows, perhaps he became a ghoul and is out there somewhere even now.
DIALOGUE AFTER: QuestGiver: Thanks to you, I can finally send that scavenger team back to the surface.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused, making a small joke / Amused

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I did you a favor, so how about you do one for me?
RESPONSE TEXT: Well, that seems only fair, I suppose.
SCRIPT NOTES: A bit flustered, you were not expecting this

RESPONSE TEXT: One of the salvage teams brought this back, and I've been trying to figure out what to do with it.
Here, perhaps it will be of some use to you.
DIALOGUE AFTER: QuestGiver: Thanks to you, I can finally send that scavenger team back to the surface.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I did you a favor, so how about you do one for me?
RESPONSE TEXT: A favor? I'm sorry, but I don't have anything to offer you.
I was led to believe you were here to help us, but perhaps I misunderstood.
DIALOGUE AFTER: QuestGiver: Thanks to you, I can finally send that scavenger team back to the surface.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I don't doubt it. Not even a bit.
RESPONSE TEXT: Thanks to you, I can finally send that scavenger team back to the surface.
Of course, there are Feral Ghouls hiding all over the Commonwealth.
I'm sure it's only a matter of time before we have to deal with them again.
If you're willing to undertake another extermination, come and see me. I can always use the help.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: NPCMAlanBinet: Another of our scavenger teams has come under attack by Feral Ghouls. There seems to be no end to the damn things.
RESPONSE TEXT: I hate to keep asking this, but there really is nobody else to turn to.
SCRIPT NOTES: Feeling a bit guilty about asking for another favor / Pleading

RESPONSE TEXT: Can you deal with those Ghouls?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I took care of them already.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I took care of them already.
RESPONSE TEXT: I thank you, and so will the synths. Being torn to bits by feral ghouls is a fate they'd very much like to avoid.
DIALOGUE AFTER: QuestGiver: Just let me know when those feral ghouls have been dealt with, and I'll put the synths back in the field.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: No, I haven't.
RESPONSE TEXT: I see.
DIALOGUE AFTER: QuestGiver: What do you say?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: No, I haven't.
RESPONSE TEXT: Well, I won't trouble you further about it, then.
DIALOGUE AFTER: QuestGiver: What do you say?

RESPONSE TEXT: It's quite simple, really. Find where the feral ghouls are making their home, and then wipe them out.
DIALOGUE AFTER: QuestGiver: What do you say?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I thank you, and so will the synths. Being torn to bits by feral ghouls is a fate they'd very much like to avoid.
RESPONSE TEXT: Just let me know when those feral ghouls have been dealt with, and I'll put the synths back in the field.

RESPONSE TEXT: What do you say?

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah, director, hello. If I may take a moment of your time, we're having some trouble on the surface.

RESPONSE TEXT: Ah, hello. If I may take a moment of your time, we're having some trouble on the surface.
DIALOGUE AFTER: QuestGiver: There's a den of those abominable Feral Ghouls that's been threatening one of our scavenger teams.

RESPONSE TEXT: Another of our scavenger teams has come under attack by Feral Ghouls. There seems to be no end to the damn things.
DIALOGUE AFTER: QuestGiver: I hate to keep asking this, but there really is nobody else to turn to.

RESPONSE TEXT: Have you changed your mind about that Feral Ghoul problem I mentioned?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I took care of them already.

RESPONSE TEXT: Someday, we should capture a feral ghoul and bring it here for study.
I've often wondered why some ghouls become feral, while others retain their intelligence.
We've lost synths to feral ghouls in the past. When we found them, well, there wasn't much left.
SCRIPT NOTES: Worried, a bit hopeless... this is a morbid subject / Concerned

RESPONSE TEXT: We'll all grieve for Father, but I know the loss must be especially difficult for you.
The future looks very bright indeed, director.
We'll all grieve for Father, but I know the loss must be especially difficult for you.
The future looks very bright indeed, director.
There's no denying it. You've impressed us.
With the reactor online, we can finally make plans to accelerate synth production.
I suppose congratulations are in order.
SCRIPT NOTES: Measured, uncertain. The player was promoted and you aren't sure it was deserved.

RESPONSE TEXT: So, you'll be our new director someday. That was... unexpected.
SCRIPT NOTES: Measured, uncertain. The player was promoted and you aren't sure it was deserved.

RESPONSE TEXT: What did you do with your day, Liam?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: You know, kept busy.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Liam: Hey, what's with the sudden security increase? I noticed a few more Coursers than usual walking around. Is everything okay?
RESPONSE TEXT: Oh it's nothing to worry about.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: In other words, it's definitely something to worry about and you can't talk about it. How bad is it?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Liam: In other words, it's definitely something to worry about and you can't talk about it. How bad is it?
RESPONSE TEXT: You're too smart Liam, but I assure you, it has nothing to do with anything that would concern you.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Liam: I think that's even more concerning.
SCRIPT NOTES: Start with a laugh. Amused, reassuring. / Amused

DIALOGUE BEFORE: InstituteScientist: SRB doesn't agree. Statistically, the gen-threes have shown an increase in autonomic behavior, suggesting a malfunction in the latest models.
RESPONSE TEXT: I assure you Doctor, that is not a malfunction.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: InstituteScientist: In light of recent events, we've been asked to take a look at the behavioral mapping in the gen-3s.
RESPONSE TEXT: I see...Another of Doctor Ayo's manipulative power plays. Well he's wrong. The Gen-threes are functioning just as designed.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: I assure you Doctor, that is not a malfunction.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: InstituteScientist: In light of recent events, we've been asked to take a look at the behavioral mapping in the gen-3s.
RESPONSE TEXT: I thought things would be better with Alana in charge. Now I see she's just as blind.
Regardless of what she might believe, she's wrong. The gen-threes are functioning perfectly.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Alan: I assure you Doctor, that is not a malfunction.

RESPONSE TEXT: Think about it, doctor. You and everyone else firmly hold onto the archaic opinion that the synths are inferior. By limiting them, we limit our work.
DIALOGUE AFTER: InstituteScientist: I am well aware of your ideas, doctor, and there is a reason they are not the popular ones.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: InstituteScientist: There needs to be a distinction between us and them.
RESPONSE TEXT: No, they are an evolution of us. The synths possess vast untapped potential, if we'd only let them show it...
DIALOGUE AFTER: InstituteScientist: I suggest you keep your radical opinions to yourself from now on.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Eve: Welcome home, Alan. How was your day?
RESPONSE TEXT: Oh, you know... prying open closed minds one at a time...
DIALOGUE AFTER: Eve: Well, you're home now, and you should relax. I got a little sidetracked helping Liam with his work, but things are under control.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Eve: Alan, why don't you relax a little. I'll take care of everything.
RESPONSE TEXT: Wonderful, Eve. I swear, I don't know what I'd do without you...
All that time, Doctor Ayo was blaming me just to keep everyone's eyes off of him. The man was utterly without scruples.
I certainly don't miss Doctor Ayo and his Coursers looking over my shoulder all day.
Now that Doctor Ayo's plot has been exposed, things are back to normal.
I'm the one who filled Liam's head with silly, idealistic notions about synths. Now I'll never see him again.
SCRIPT NOTES: Depressed, broken, your have lost your son

RESPONSE TEXT: I hoped one day that Liam would work alongside me. No all I can do is hope that he's still alive up there.
SCRIPT NOTES: Depressed, broken, your have lost your son

RESPONSE TEXT: I have failed completely as a father. There's no other way to put it.
SCRIPT NOTES: Depressed, broken, your have lost your son

RESPONSE TEXT: If only I'd paid more attention to Liam, to what he was doing... Maybe I could saved him.
SCRIPT NOTES: Depressed, broken, your have lost your son

RESPONSE TEXT: I've been avoiding my quarters. I can't bear to be there wihtout Liam. Too many memories...
SCRIPT NOTES: Depressed, broken, your have lost your son

RESPONSE TEXT: How does one cope with the loss of a child? Where do you even start?
SCRIPT NOTES: Depressed, broken, your have lost your son
